utterances: For scientists these days, probing the secrets of plants at the genetic level is all the rage.
Here's NPR's Joe Palca to tell us about two especially interesting plants.
If you're wondering how exactly it is that plants help fuel the world, Jody Banks has the answer.
When you burn coal today, or actually the fossil fuel, the fossil is a fossil of the relatives of Selaginella.
Jody Banks is a botanist at Purdue University.
Selaginella is smallish plant, about six inches tall.
It's found all over the world.
Banks says Selaginella represents an important step in the evolution of plants.
It's one of the first to develop a system of tubing for transporting water and other nutrients from one end of the plant to the other.
You can only reach a certain height before, you know, you have to be able to - you have to have tubing to conduct the water from the ground to the top of the plant.
If you remember your high school biology, those tubes are called xylem and phloem, and plants wouldn't get far without them.
Besides tubing, Selagninella has something else you should know about.
Now we're going to talk about plant secondary metabolites.
Okay, wait a minute.
Let me get myself seated comfortably.
Okay.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
As Banks reports in the current issue of the journal Science, Selaginella is chockfull of genes that make these secondary metabolites.
So what that means is that Selaginella is likely to make many, many, many secondary compounds, and they're most likely going to be unique.
Another important plant getting a genomic working over is amborella.
Victor Albert of the University at Buffalo says amborella doesn't look all that important.
It basically just looks like a small tree or shrub with fairly non-descript leaves and relatively non-descript flowers, and it produces berries.
But those non-descript flowers turn out from one of the first flowering plants that evolved on Earth.
Somewhere around maybe 130 or more million years ago, the flowing plants first emerged.
And the flower was a great innovation.
At the House of Commons in London last week, Scottish parliamentarian Ian Blackford made it very clear why.
I'm Melissa Block.
And we're reporting all this week from Chengdu, China.
Chengdu is the capital of Sichuan, the province that bore the overwhelming brunt of last Monday's earthquake.
But Chengdu emerged pretty much unscathed.
This is a huge city, with a population ranging from four to 11 million, depending on how much surrounding area you include.
And it's safe to say the population of Chengdu will balloon as the people displaced by the earthquake make their way here to the big city.
Chengdu is a boom town.
There's lots of foreign investment here.
Intel is here.
Motorola, Microsoft - many others.
You have to hunt pretty hard to find any trace of old Chengdu, a city that dates back more than 2,000 years to the Han Dynasty.
And if you find something that looks old, it probably isn't.
Case in point: When I was here in April, we went to a tiny street that's considered the beating heart of old Chengdu, the last remnant of the old city.
It was in the midst of a radical makeover.
(Soundbite of hammering)
Here's an example of how Chengdu is redoing itself.
We've come to Jae Chungsa(ph), which means Narrow Alley.
It's a street that was filled with homes.
They've all been torn down, and they're getting rebuilt in the old style - beautiful homes with brick and curved roofs that are tiled with decorative trim on the outside.
It all looks very old.
In fact, it's brand new.
These were homes.
They're going to be turned into businesses - restaurants and bars, so that this will be a tourist attraction in Chengdu.
(Soundbite of rustling, machine sounds)
The workers who are doing all of this manual labor get 60 quai a day.
That's a little over $8.
They work from 7:30 in the morning till midnight.
They get a half-hour break for lunch and a half-hour break for dinner.
(Foreign language spoken)
(Soundbite of saw)
A lot of sparks flying in the middle of this courtyard as they're putting the finishing touches on this building.
This building has an emblem on the outside of two fish jumping out of the water.
And the smell is of fresh lacquer and stone and wood shavings.
(Soundbite of saw)
A few women just went by with wheelbarrows full of wood, and these are not young women.
These are older women who are hard at work on this project.
(Soundbite of saw)
(Soundbite of wheelbarrows rolling)
(Soundbite of crowd chatter)
A man running by with a heavy wheelbarrow full of stones.
They are under a lot of pressure to get this done fast.
This whole street needs to be finished by May.
That's less than a month.
And it looks they've got a long way to go.
Fast forward to May.
I went back to Narrow Alley yesterday.
What a difference a month makes.
We've come back now to Narrow Alley.
It's not done.
It has not been completed yet, but buildings are going up on all sides.
There is an ad right here on this building, this grey stone building for Walden(ph) Cafe.
We've come back today with NPR's Beijing correspondent Anthony Kuhn.

Anthony, this is a sign I imagine you have seen all around China in the many years you've lived here - old buildings being torn down, new ones going up - in this case, new buildings to look like they're old.
That's right.
It's essentially a reconstituted old street.
Most of the buildings here are essentially redone.
In some cases, it's because the original quality of the construction is not that good.
But I think there's also just a preoccupation with newness, a feeling that old things are just not worth saving, and people are ready to move on.
There's not very much sentimentality about saving old buildings.
This street's being marketed to businesses who might want to come here as an irreplaceable symbol of old Chengdu - historic, irreplaceable, but it was torn down and rebuilt.
Yes.
And you walk through here, you can't help but think of where are the people now who used to live here?
And I imagine they're out in the countryside or in the suburbs in much less expensive quarters.
The thing is, of course, that in all of these old neighborhoods, this land is right in the center of town, and it's become extremely expensive.
And I think in many of these neighborhoods, the developers have made a lot of money by turning this into upscale shopping areas.

And one of the reason the developers make so much money is that the residents often get less than market value for their homes, and so many of the residents often complain that they're not able to buy new housing with the amount that they're given.
Here's a building that has a metal sign above the gate and Chinese characters.
I see a wine glass.
I'm assuming this is a bar, Anthony.
Or it will be a bar.
It certainly isn't yet.
Mid Touch is the translation in English.
What is it in Chinese?
In Chinese, it says (Chinese spoken), which perhaps means slightly inebriated.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Or mid-touch.
That's right.
When we were here a month ago, this street was a complete beehive of activity.
And there are some workers working today.
It is the lunch hour, so it's a little slower.
But we've also heard that a lot of these workers are from the countryside, and when the earthquake hit, they left.
They went home to check on their families.
They're just not here.
Well, that's how Chinese cities are built these days, with workers from the countryside.
They don't have a lot of benefits.
They don't have a lot of safety nets to back them up in case of accidents like this.
So the impact on the whole urban development, I think, is going to be quite something here.
It's going to be quite severe.
At one end of Narrow Alley, Anthony Kuhn and I found Yu Bo outside the restaurant that bears his name - the Yu family restaurant.
He was bending down next to a purple tent set up just outside the entrance.
Are you sleeping here?
No, no.
No, he said.
He was just showing his 12-year-old daughter how to put the tent together in case there's another aftershock.
Yu Bo is the restaurant owner and head chef.
On a normal day, he'd be preparing an elaborate banquet meal - 30 courses for each table, dishes of intricate construction, including a traditional Sichuan dessert.
(Chinese spoken)
